business.start.para: Mr SPEAKER (Mr Neil Andrew) took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties, I present the committee's Report No. 33, entitled Social security agreement with Italy and New Zealand committee exchange, together with the minutes of proceedings and the evidence received by the committee.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: —The report contains advice on two separate issues: firstly, the results of a review by the treaties committee of the social security agreement between Australia and Italy; and, secondly, a report on the visit the treaties committee made to New Zealand in March this year as part of the parliamentary committee exchange program.

speech.para: First off, I will talk about the social security agreement with Italy. Agreements such as this highlight the importance of treaty making. It demonstrates that treaties are not just about handing over sovereignty but about cooperating with other nations to ensure that the interests of both communities are protected and, indeed, advanced. Australia is a party to nine bilateral social security agreements, all of which are designed to provide welfare protection to people who move between different countries and Australia. This agreement with Italy benefits about 41,000 former Italian residents who live in Australia now and about 15,000 former Australian residents who now live in Italy. It is expected to facilitate the payment of about $166 million in pension payments from Italy into Australia and about $48 million from Australia into Italy.

During the review, we heard from Italian welfare organisations, known as Patronati, who spoke out strongly in support of this agreement. Other community groups who had been kept informed about the progress of the agreement were likewise supportive of our ratifying the agreement. The agreement is an update of the current 1986 agreement, so it largely reflects changes in policies and legislation in both countries. The committee, of course, recommended that binding action be taken.

Regarding the visit to New Zealand in March this year, the exchange program provided us with a terrific opportunity to meet a lot of people from different parts of the government and the parliament in New Zealand, especially those with an interest in the parliamentary review of treaty making. The centrepiece of the visit was our meeting with the New Zealand parliament's committee on foreign affairs, defence and trade, or their select committee as they call them. During this meeting we examined the approach that both parliaments take in reviewing treaty actions.

There are similarities of course—as one would hope and expect. In both parliaments, proposed treaty actions are tabled before binding treaty action is taken, national interest analyses are tabled and both committees are expected to report on proposed treaty actions within 15 sitting days. The major difference in the treatment of treaties between the two countries is that here in Australia the treaties committee reviews and reports on all proposed treaty actions, whereas in New Zealand the Select Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade may examine a treaty itself, or it may refer it to another select committee with more technical expertise.

During the exchange, we had some valuable discussions with other New Zealand parliamentarians, the President of the Law Commission, Justice David Baragwanath and Sir Kenneth Keith, a judge of the New Zealand Court of Appeal. All of the discussions confirmed our view that parliamentary consideration of proposed treaty actions is an essential part of a modern democracy. The scope and the impact of international law are growing at a pace that is not going to diminish. If anything, there are going to be more and more treaties and such international agreements will become the normal part of government. It is vital that governments participate in the development of this law. We in Australia should have a say not just in the specific treaties that we sign and ratify but how they are being made generally in a modern sense. It is also, of course, vital that parliamentarians, who represent the interests of communities—particularly electorates, in the case of MPs or, for senators, the more general community—also have a chance to have a say in this process. We have to ensure that international law develops in a way that not only reflects the interests of specific lobby groups and all sorts of weird little NGOs you find around the place but reflects and promotes local priorities. It is the interests of the people who elect us to this parliament that we have to represent when we review treaties.

Mr Speaker, we are grateful we have had the opportunity to learn more about New Zealand and its parliament's response to these challenges. We are also grateful we have had the opportunity to debate and reflect upon some emerging issues in treaty making in a way, you could say, that our day-to-day work does not always allow. I commend the report to the House. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The first part of Report No. 33, Social security treaty with Italy and New Zealand committee exchange deals with the updating of the 1986 agreement, with changes in policy and legislation in both Australia and Italy. The treaty dealing with social security is the largest shared social security agreement we have, benefiting about 41,000 former Italian residents in Australia and about 15,000 former Australian residents now living in Italy. It was Australia's first shared responsibility agreement, an approach that has now been replicated in agreements with Canada, Spain, Malta, the Netherlands, Ireland, Portugal, Austria and Cyprus. The idea of the updated agreement is to take into account the changes made in policy and legislation in both countries since 1986. I certainly support those changes and recommend them to the House.

speech.para: The second part of the report, as the chairman of the committee has just reported, deals with the committee's visit to New Zealand, a visit which allowed the committee to meet with a range of people and organisations interested in treaty making, plus the parliamentarians of New Zealand who are dealing with treaty making there, along with people such as Sir Kenneth Keith, who is the review judge at the present moment and was in the Law Reform Commission before that. He is one of their eminent minds and the committee certainly gained a lot of insight by spending some time with him and discussing treaty making and the effect on domestic law and appellant law as well. We had a meeting with the Speaker of the House of Representatives and discussed with him the whole aspect of their select committee system and treaty making. It was also interesting that they certainly promote the concept of having women in the parliament, and I made a note that 30 per cent of their parliamentarians are women.

The Law Reform Commission meeting with Justice Baragwanath and his fellow commissioners was of great significance. It was important to talk with them about the significance, as they see it, of the difficulties emerging in the world with e-commerce, cross-border insolvent companies and issues such as computer crime and about how we deal with those and the need for treaty making for countries to deal with those issues. They were well advanced, and one of their commissioners had recently returned from the US and was able to join us and discuss his recent trip and the work he had done there.

The time we spent there was very significant, and it was time well spent, Mr Speaker, I can assure you. The shared responsibility between both countries and the ability to go between one country and another and discuss these issues give you insights into the way another country might look slightly differently at things. We are reasonably close to New Zealand and our laws come from a common background but they do look at things slightly differently. We talked about the Treaty of Waitangi with them, and the common law notions of equality and property law that that treaty gives them, and about dealing with that through the Maori land courts and what they are doing there.

The situation of resolving conflicts that arise between the laws of different countries is something that is going to arise more and more. We are going to have to come to grips with those and deal with them. As e-commerce comes in more and more, we will certainly need more treaty making to try to resolve those issues. As we discussed with the New Zealanders, we will endeavour to be there at the forefront to solve them. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to join with my colleagues the member for Wentworth and the member for Lyons in regard to this 33rd report from the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties in the four-year history of the committee. Thirty-three reports would, I think, stand out again as evidence of the amount of work we do. As the member for Lyons rightly said, we are going to see more and more treaties, not fewer. As nations of the world find the barriers between them regarding their commerce and conduct becoming less obvious, we are going to have to ensure—just as we have laws in this country to sort out disagreements—that the paths of conduct of commerce are smooth, so treaties between nations are going to become more prevalent.

speech.para: In that regard, the work of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties, as an example of world's best practice, is enjoyed in this parliament. The people of Australia also value the fact that we have bothered to inquire into some things that, in the past, were not inquired into. The first of the two matters disclosed in this report to the people of Australia is the social security agreement with Italy. At first brush, the national interests analysis and the commonsense involving the $166 million and the 41,000 former Italian residents now residing in Australia—and, for that matter, the 15,000 former Australians now residing in Italy—all seemed as though it was matter-of-fact and one wondered if there was much point in inquiring deeper into it.

The committee resolved that it wanted to take submissions from people and it sought a cross-section of views, as we always do, including through advertisements in national publications and also specialist press publications, such as El Globo and other Italian community newspapers. This was done for a reason. Whenever treaties are signed in this nation now, it is no longer just a plaything for the executive and the bureaucracy: through this place, we bring the people into the picture and we keep the people well informed about what is going on. It is all there for them to see in Report 33, and I would of course recommend that anybody interested in these matters look closely at it.

With regard to the trip to the New Zealand parliament, it was sponsored by the New Zealand parliament as part of a regular exchange program where one committee per year travels from their country to ours and one from ours to theirs. We do not make a lot of trips to that nation so close to us, but they wanted to talk to us and to compare what they had done in their treaty making revision with what we have been doing. I think it was a very fruitful couple of days.

New Zealand has in so many ways followed our lead and whilst, as the chairman, the member for Wentworth, rightly pointed out, they allow their Select Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to arbitrate whether matters are referred to other specialist committees, the committee here in Australia does not allow itself to be in any way, shape or form accused of being captured by client groups, as could be the case with specialist committees. Let us face it, a committee constantly dealing with a department can become a little too close on occasions. The Joint Standing Committee on Treaties in this parliament make it a habit of taking no prisoners and ensuring that different departments well know that we apply the same standards of inquiry and demands for disclosure no matter what department it is. So we are right into accountability of the executive, as the New Zealand parliament have shown us they are too.

The meetings we had with top ranking lawyers and people involved in reform processes, and the discovery of other international linkages at their level, were also very fruitful. I think the committee gained from them a very strong view as far as our role is concerned and its importance in the Australian context. Whilst New Zealand has so many systems similar to ours—legal, political, social, cultural, economic and values; and we play football and cricket, although, fortunately, better than New Zealand—I think it is always good to have the opportunity to go and test our own particular credentials and efforts on behalf of the people of Australia beside those in that country so close to us. I think in that regard this place provides a ready forum for us all to trust the people, to ensure the people are satisfied that the executive—the members of the cabinet and the ministry—are acting on behalf of all Australians, and I am proud to be part of the revised treaty making process that is making it happen.

talk.start.para: —I would like to speak to Report No. 33, Social security agreement with Italy and New Zealand committee exchange, and I am pleased to do so. I also would like to comment on the committee's visit to New Zealand. The visit, as the previous speaker, the member for Moreton, said, was sponsored by the New Zealand government, and I thank them for giving us that opportunity because it provided us with an opportunity to see first-hand the treaty review process of our very close neighbours. New Zealand's process has really only come into practice since May 1998 when the house adopted sessional orders requiring the government to present proposed treaty actions to the government and allow select committees to review and report on such actions.

speech.para: It can be argued that New Zealand's process is, while similar to our own, not as transparent and does not allow the same input from the general community as does the process set in place by the Howard government. As I have said before—and I will say it again, because I am very proud of the fact—it was the Howard government that lifted the veil of secrecy on the process of international treaty making in this country. We have given the process back to the people of Australia. During the term in office of the previous government there were over 500 treaties agreed to without any consultation with the Australian public. The previous government were not even required to bring them to the attention of the parliament, and it is justifiable that many Australians felt hostility towards these secret agreements that the government had entered into on behalf of the nation. They saw them as a threat to Australia sovereignty, and they had little knowledge of their contents and purposes.

The New Zealand experience was very similar. The members of their Select Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade whom we met with said that the parliamentary review process was introduced in response to general community concerns about the closed nature of treaty making. It was the same sense of community concern that alienated the Australian public also, and that led us to promise, when we were elected in 1996, that we would take that back to the people. One of the first things that the government did when we came into office in 1996 was to involve the Australian public and also concerned community groups in our process of considering and agreeing to treaties with other nations. We have set in place an extensive consultation process, including public hearings, so that all Australians can have their say before any decision is taken. As I said, it compares very favourably with the process that they have devised in New Zealand, which is outlined in this report. I believe our government's transparent approach and the fact that we have very simple criteria upon which we judge any proposed agreements has led to an easing of community concern.

Our overarching consideration—the bottom line, if you like—when it comes to deciding whether or not we enter into an agreement is a simple question: is it in Australia's best interests to do so? The very best test is that if the answer is no then we are not interested, and there are no ifs, buts or maybes. I believe that has gone some way to restore the public's faith in our international treaty making process. But there is still a wariness, and it is important we keep working, particularly as members of this committee, to encourage greater community participation and make sure that Australians are aware that their input is welcome and that the opportunity now exists for them to have their say. Certainly there still are some sections of the community which, for their own purposes, want to perpetuate the idea that foreign agreements are being made in secret and Australia is being robbed of its sovereignty. They feed on discontent and want to create an impression that nothing has changed, but in fact a great deal has changed. The very existence of this committee and the reviews we conduct around the country are clear evidence of our commitment to lifting the veil of secrecy.

I join other members in thanking those parliamentary members and legal and constitutional experts who met with us in New Zealand to give us the benefit of their experience. It is this ongoing mutual exchange of ideas and knowledge that will forge even closer ties between Australia and New Zealand, to the benefit of both nations. I look forward to meeting with New Zealand's House of Representatives Select Committee on Social Affairs during their visit to Canberra this week.

talk.start.para: —I also would like to make a few comments on this report, especially on a matter that has been of some concern to me over many years—that is, the social security agreements. I was one of the members here when we signed the first social security agreement with Italy, and I must say I think that did create the pattern for other agreements. But I do want to commend the committee for its report and for its support of this agreement. I was a little bit concerned about the delay from 1993 until 2002 in the finalisation of this treaty. There were some technical matters. There were also some matters of policy that the government was concerned with and wanted to sort out. Nevertheless, I am very pleased that it has sorted them out and that this agreement has proceeded. I just wanted to make the point too that I support the committee's general conclusion at paragraph 2.14, which says:

quote.para: As noted in our Report 32, Six Treaties Tabled on 7 March 2000 (May 2000), when commenting on a proposed Social Security Agreement with Denmark, we support the principle of establishing a network of bilateral agreements to give better welfare protection to people who move between countries. Such agreements are to the benefit of the individuals and the governments involved in these schemes.

speech.para: The Italian agreement has been of great importance to people of Italian background in Australia. It did, as I say, provide the basis on which a number of other agreements were signed. It is, however, to be pointed out that, unfortunately, there have been hold-ups and delays in relation to social security agreements with some countries. I have raised this matter with the minister in questions on notice. In particular, I would like to emphasise the fact that a number of our major ethnic communities are still awaiting agreements to be finalised. I refer here in particular to the Croatian community, to the Greek community and to the German community—three cases that I have actually raised with the minister. I do not know whether the treaties committee can help us in relation to this, but I am very concerned about the fact that there have been constant delays in these three cases. I think that we ought to take up the example we have here in terms of finalisation of the Italian agreement and try to secure agreements with especially these three countries—and with other countries—where we have initiated discussions but have not proceeded to the finalisation of them.

I know that the minister has said that she has tried to negotiate—with ministers in Greece, for example, in the case of the agreement with Greece—and there have been some problems on both sides. I am not throwing all of the difficulties onto the minister here. But as someone who is in touch with these three communities in particular, I do say that the communities are all concerned—whatever the case may be; whether it is the Australian government or whether it is in fact the governments over there—that these agreements have not been concluded. I take this opportunity to ask the government to do what it can to please move these forward on behalf of those communities which are quite anxious to achieve social security agreements, for example, Greece, Croatia, Germany and other countries, where they are awaiting these results. In some cases, the negotiations have been going on for a hell of a long time—many years—and it is time that some way was found to break through the bureaucratic problems, to resolve these issues and to form those social security agreements. I commend the report to the House.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the House take note of the report.

speech.para: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —In accordance with standing order 102b, the debate is interrupted. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting and the member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

—On behalf of the Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs I present the committee's report on the inquiry into indigenous health, entitled Health is life, together with evidence received by the committee.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to table this report on indigenous health by the Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs. The inquiry into indigenous health commenced in the last parliament. At the outset, I would like to thank the previous members of that committee, particularly the member for Mallee, Mr John Forrest, my predecessor as committee chairman. They established a solid basis of information for the present committee to work from, as well as creating a very positive, bipartisan and cooperative approach that has continued to characterise the conduct of this inquiry. The goodwill established by the members of the committee, both past and present, is, I hope, an example for all, particularly governments, the general public and the indigenous community, who will have to work together if progress is to be made.

speech.para: The title of this report, Health is life, reflects a fundamental difference between the way that indigenous and non-indigenous Australians consider health issues. For non-indigenous Australians health is normally considered to relate to the general condition of the body and mind. For indigenous Australians health is not the same concept. Some say that it encompasses much more and relates to every aspect of their lives—physical, social and spiritual. This profound difference in world view presents a significant challenge for all, but particularly governments and the health profession. It is something we as a nation have grappled with for some time, and the many efforts of successive governments have left us at a loss to know what to do for the best.

There is currently a very significant taxpayer commitment from the Commonwealth government, which now spends around $2.3 billion annually on all indigenous specific programs. Government expenditure on indigenous health programs alone represents around 2.2 per cent of all recurrent health expenditure, which is roughly in line with the percentage that indigenous people make up of the Australian population. Parliamentary committees seem to almost always demand more money from executive government. Whilst we have submitted some suggestions to government in this report, we believe much more research is needed before a final definitive amount could be agreed upon.

There have been a lot of previous reports on indigenous health issues, but the committee found that most of the recommendations from these earlier reports have not been implemented or fully effected. Our failure to make significant progress in this area stands in contrast to the situation of the indigenous populations of New Zealand, Canada and the United States. I am sure there are many and varied reasons for this and experiences are not necessarily transferable; however, experiences in these other countries offer hope that improvement is possible over the medium and longer term. There has to be leadership at a national, state, territory and community level to develop and implement the many strategies that can overcome the more serious issues. Most importantly, there has to be strong Commonwealth leadership. The committee found that the planning and delivery of health and related services for indigenous Australians is broadly characterised by a general lack of direction and poor coordination. Services and programs are delivered by a mixture of Commonwealth, state, territory and local government agencies. There is no clear delineation or agreement about which level of government is ultimately responsible for ensuring the continued improvement in the health of Australia's indigenous population.

The Commonwealth focuses mainly on primary care, through Medicare payments and grants to the Aboriginal medical services. The states and territories focus mainly on acute care but provide primary care through hospital outpatients and community health programs. Additionally, they provide some support for specific population programs through the Aboriginal medical services. There also appears to be little, if any, coordination between these diverse health programs and programs in other areas important to health and wellbeing such as environmental health, provision of infrastructure, education and employment. The outcome of these piecemeal funding and coordination arrangements is fragmented policy and programs across the states, territories and the Commonwealth.

The committee believes, however, that the biggest barrier to progress has been the lack of any real efforts to integrate indigenous community involvement into the planning and delivery of health and related services. This problem involves the mainstream health system and the Aboriginal medical services, which are at times reluctant to come together. In fact, some people acknowledge that a state of conflict can help justify the continuing funding of some services. The committee understands that indigenous communities are not all the same and that the levels of services that are needed will vary considerably between each community. However, if services are to be effective, there is a need for greater collaboration at all levels.

It is unlikely that the health of indigenous Australians will improve significantly until the fragmentation of services, cost shifting and lack of agreement about responsibility for indigenous health are fully addressed. The committee believes that for this to happen there must be a clear and specific agreement between the states and the Commonwealth. These agreements need to address not only the respective responsibilities but also how those responsibilities are to be acted upon and the level of resources to be committed by each party. The framework agreements are a reasonable start. The committee considers that there are two main prerequisites that will need to be satisfied before there can be any significant improvement in the health and wellbeing of indigenous Australians.

Firstly, the Commonwealth has to adopt a more central and active role in the coordination, planning, delivery and monitoring of health and related services for indigenous Australians. Secondly, the indigenous community has to be allowed to play—and accept that they must play—a far greater role in those same areas. To support the Commonwealth in adopting such a central leadership role the committee has recommended that a National Council of Indigenous Health Affairs be established. This council would advise governments on the coordination of the necessary activity across all areas that impact on indigenous health and wellbeing and across all levels of government. The national council must comprise indigenous and non-indigenous experts in the fields of health, housing, education, employment, culture, planning, management and administration. The council would bring together those people who are most able to unite the community, both indigenous and non-indigenous, and governments to focus on improving the health of indigenous Australians. This council would report regularly to the Prime Minister, and annually to the parliament, about progress in improving indigenous health. In particular they would identify any major barriers to achieving further progress. In accepting the need for leadership on this matter, the Commonwealth also needs to recognise that there will need to be a concerted and continued effort across a range of Commonwealth portfolios for a considerable period.

Changes in health outcomes will not be achieved in the short term and there will need to be a committed and bipartisan approach. To support the Commonwealth's effort to achieve effective coordination, the committee believes there will need to be senior representation at the highest levels of government. The committee believes that this must be at the most senior ministerial level and has consequently recommended that the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs be placed in cabinet. This would involve an increased level of responsibility for monitoring and coordinating Commonwealth initiatives impacting on indigenous health across all programs. The committee is not proposing any changes in the current portfolio arrangements for specific programs. The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs would not assume responsibility for any programs currently delivered through other portfolios but would, instead, be responsible for ensuring that all those portfolios work closer together, improving indigenous health outcomes.

The committee also believes that, as part of this new role, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs should report annually to parliament about the progress of government actions across all portfolios to improve indigenous health and wellbeing. The report would provide a benchmark against which to monitor improvements, or otherwise, in indigenous health, education and employment. As I indicated earlier, as well as the need for the Commonwealth to play a central role, there is a need to ensure that the indigenous community play an active and effective role in the planning and delivery of services for their own community. This means that the community controlled services need to be adequately resourced. Sufficient resources need to be provided for an appropriate level of health care to the community as well as to allow effective and equal community participation in the planning and monitoring of services. We have, I emphasise, suggested that considerable research is needed to accurately document what is appropriate. To support the community in these roles the committee has recommended that a new funding approach be developed. This new approach builds on existing trials by the Commonwealth and provides for a pooling of Commonwealth, state, territory and community funds at the regional level. The community will then play the primary role in determining the allocation and use of these funds. It is proposed that additional Commonwealth funding be allocated over the next four years to support this approach. This is based on the understanding that current Medicare arrangements do not suit much of the indigenous population—like, I might add, much of regional Australia. The states and territories are then meeting the costs of providing services which are normally met by the Commonwealth for the non-indigenous population. The committee believes these measures have to be associated with an increased focus on improving the coordination of health services with other sectors—in particular, the provision of education and the development of programs to significantly enhance employment opportunities.

There needs to be a greater focus on meeting the backlog of need in terms of housing and other infrastructure, particularly potable water. In providing improved facilities, greater emphasis needs to be given to the adequate and ongoing maintenance of those facilities. The problems are difficult, but they are not insurmountable. There are practical and effective strategies that can be implemented, which the report has attempted to highlight. The committee's findings are not particularly new. They have been highlighted in many of the reports into indigenous health that have been presented over the last 20 years. Progress can be made in indigenous health only with strong cooperative partnerships between the indigenous community and the Commonwealth, the states and the territories. Goals which allow for an incremental approach can help maintain morale and encourage those most affected. This is not to say that we can move slowly on this problem; rather that a cooperative assessment of what is achievable is more likely to achieve results. Support for strong bottom-up leadership in the indigenous community, along with more effective administration and relevant education, is the key to making the concept of community participation work.

On behalf of the committee, I particularly want to thank the members of the communities and hope we can do justice to their views. Finally, I would like to thank all committee members and the personnel of the secretariat for their wonderful assistance in the conduct of this important inquiry. I would especially like to acknowledge the support of Jim Kennedy and wish him all the best in the future. I commend the report to the House.

talk.start.para: —It is indeed a great privilege for me to speak today on the tabling of Health is life, the report of the inquiry into indigenous health by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs. This inquiry was first adopted in the last parliament. While it is fair to say that at the outset it was clear this was to be an important, probably long and definitely difficult and emotional inquiry, nothing could have prepared me for the journey on which I was embarking. The committee membership has changed over that time. This inquiry has been under the guidance of three different chairs. However, during the 2½ years of work, the committee has remained steadfast in its determination to reach an outcome which we all fervently trust will assist in furthering the health and wellbeing of our Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

speech.para: There is no doubting the statistics that the level of health experienced by our indigenous population should be of deep concern to all Australians and that some drastic steps are needed to reach acceptable standards in this area. Some people may still have the view that all Australians should be dealt with equally and that expenditure should reflect that view. This view is completely untenable while the level of health problems in our indigenous population is so severely out of step with that of non-indigenous Australians. We need to spend appropriately to improve indigenous health, and we need all governments—I emphasise `all governments'—to adopt a short-, medium- and long-term view of the problem. While there are some areas of health that can be improved in the shorter term, many issues are longer term and intergenerational. Budget and planning considerations must take all of this into the equation. Consistency must be evident and, most importantly, trust must be given.

We must acknowledge where improvements and gains are there to be seen. In some areas of indigenous health, the improvements are clearly evident. We must learn from these experiences and apply those lessons wherever possible. In the course of the inquiry, we have travelled to many communities: remote, rural, regional, outer urban and city. In fact, we have had the privilege of visiting communities in some of the most remote areas of Australia. We have met with hundreds of individuals and groups. We have seen some of the most wonderful examples of dedication, determination, belief, optimism and sheer hard work. We have seen all of this despite the desperate need for assistance and despite the fact that in some cases resources are appallingly poor. Even with the greatest of intent, we have seen that improvement in local health issues seems years away at best. We have heard stories of tragedy, of sadness and of desperation; yet through all of this these people were willing to continue working for a better health outcome for themselves and for their communities. They shared their lives with us.

The only way we could hear and learn so much was through the generosity of heart and spirit, the warmth, the trust and the goodwill of the people we met. It is no secret that there have been numerous inquiries of different sorts into indigenous affairs over the years. In fact, I believe that on this committee we were extremely aware that many of these people and communities were unfortunately very used to seeing yet another group of politicians or bureaucrats invade their country and their lives. Who could blame them if they imagined we were involved in producing another report to fill up a bookshelf somewhere? Yet this did not affect them in their willingness to talk to us, to explain their views, to give us their own local ideas of how to tackle certain issues and to talk very frankly about the problems they face each day, about the overt and covert aspects of racism and sometimes about the difficulties they have to deal with in their own communities—the things that affect them every day of their lives.

These people shared their personal and family experiences with us in ways that I believe many of us would not find possible. We saw many examples where the line of responsibility between layers of government and authority was blurred, to say the least. We saw communities badly served by the way in which services were built or supplied. We saw houses built but with no drinkable water connected or built with little or no regard for local custom, climate or need. We saw airstrips unsafe for night landing, making medical evacuation difficult. We saw roads impassable during certain climatic periods of the year and roads so rough as to make ambulance travel more perilous than acceptable. We saw some communities with only one nursing sister on call all day every day and, surprise surprise, staff cannot be retained for a longer period. We have attempted in this report to address these types of issues—the structural arrangements which involve local, state, territory and Commonwealth governments as well as all local authorities and communities.

Sometimes words can seem a bit inadequate. However, my thanks and the committee's thanks go to each and every one of the people we met and talked with. I will long remember their contributions to this inquiry and, through that, the trust they placed in us. While aware of the difficulty in mentioning one individual—it is a very dangerous thing to do but I am going to—I believe I must make mention of Mr Puggy Hunter, who was Chairperson of NACCHO, the National Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisation, for much of this inquiry. Puggy went out of his way to assist the committee, travelling with us on some occasions and offering invaluable advice on both culture and health when we were consulting different people, groups and communities. I will always value very much the counsel that was offered by Puggy to me personally and to the committee. While we sometimes found ourselves in the middle of pretty vigorous debate on certain issues—it is after all a parliamentary committee—this committee have worked very well across political differences, acknowledging differing opinion but with one goal in mind: to try to contribute to improving the health and wellbeing of our indigenous communities.

The member for Mallee, who chaired this committee until the last election, must be acknowledged. The current chair, the member for Grey, Barry Wakelin, has steered us through the debates—sometimes I am not quite sure how—and has always been willing to hear and consider all views. I thank him for his perseverance and patience. I thank my committee colleagues, both current and past, for their patience, their advice and their comradeship during this journey. This has been a long inquiry, involving a great amount of detail and information. We have undertaken numerous visits, involving a high level of organisational administration. I would like to place on record the work of the committee secretariat, led until only recently by Mr Bjarne Nordin. Mr Jim Kennedy, who was seconded to this inquiry, has overseen the final writing of the report. To Bjarne, to Jim and to everyone involved at that level, I give my thanks for, and my acknowledgment of, your valuable work.

The overwhelming impression I have gained from this inquiry is the strong belief I now have that when talking about issues in indigenous health there is, firstly, the need to acknowledge the work and the dedication already evident by those working in indigenous health and the improvements they are making. Secondly, we must listen to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and the communities and learn from them. Instead of telling them how to deal with these problems and then probably criticising them if they get it wrong, we must listen to them and work together with them in partnership. There is no doubt at all in my mind about their knowledge, their concern and their determination. I urge all those interested in this whole subject to read all of this report, allowing full understanding of the considerations and the recommendations in which we found ourselves involved. In closing, I sincerely hope that this is the last time a report is needed for any parliament to consider the poor state of health of our indigenous people. I trust that any future report will be one that measures the improvements made. If everyone involved in indigenous health—indigenous and non-indigenous Australians—all approach the future work and developments in this area in the bipartisan way of this committee, this will be the final such report.

talk.start.para: —I speak today on the tabling of this report Health is life from the Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs with the fervent hope that in 10 or 20 years time other honourable members in this place will come to the chamber to speak of marked improvements in indigenous health. It is something that we are not able to do up to today, despite many inquiries and reports over the past 20 years. It is clear that, as this report outlines, the whole issue of indigenous health is a complex one. Yet, as a mother and a pragmatist, I cannot help but feel that basic health services for all Australians ought to be a fairly simple matter, a simple matter of ensuring that practical services are provided where they are needed most—whether that be in remote Far North Queensland or in Redfern in Sydney.

speech.para: I also cannot help but feel that this is one indigenous issue upon which the whole Australian community can unite, if the issue is given the prominence it deserves, because no Australian wants to see their fellow Australians living in Third World standards and suffering preventable diseases. I wholeheartedly support the concept of reconciliation, but I cannot help but feel it has to be more practical. First and foremost, it has to be about making sure that indigenous people have the basics most Australians take for granted, like decent housing, health and education. It is a fact that those pushing for things like a treaty enjoy very comfortable housing and decent health services themselves that many indigenous Australians simply do not—and they should be our first priority.

Certainly, on our visits to remote communities, local community leaders were much more interested in discussing how housing and basic services can be improved than in discussing land rights or treaties. As someone who has been an active member of this committee on this inquiry for the three years, I believe that most of the recommendations of this report are fundamentally sensible. It is important that we quantify the extent of the problem, that we devise measures and set benchmarks so that we can gauge how effective future policies are in addressing major health and housing problems. That has been patently lacking in the past.

Annual reporting to the parliament on the state of indigenous health will provide an opportunity to see whether progress is being made and to identify what is working. But to do so will require a much greater level of cooperation and responsibility from all stakeholders—governments of all levels, health care workers and indigenous leaders. There seems to be an overriding reluctance to provide statistics and results. It is even seen as paternalistic by some sectors for governments to ask for them. Yet there is a clear responsibility that results ought to be examined if we are to find what is working, and they must be correlated against government funding—not just for accountability purposes to make sure that taxpayers' money is not being wasted but, more importantly, so we can find the programs that are working and direct funding where it is needed most. I am disappointed that this has not been one of the recommendations within this report. I firmly believe that future funding of indigenous health services ought to be clearly driven by outcomes—that is, in terms of the number of patients treated.

Early in the inquiry I remember visiting one health service that was packed to the rafters with people who genuinely needed help. The health care workers were very dedicated, devoting a great deal of additional time to seeing people, and the facilities were used to capacity. Clearly, more funding for this centre would have made an enormous difference. Another centre I visited was pristine and exceedingly well staffed, yet seemed to resemble the famed hospital in Yes, Minister. They had a huge operating budget and kept many people employed but there was a lack of patients. Clearly, more funding is needed to address indigenous health in this country, but I have also seen many things during the inquiry to suggest that it is not so much the amount of funding that is important but how we direct that funding .

Five short minutes is not long enough to outline all my views on this important issue, but I want to ensure that this report is not lost in the mire of parliamentary reports and that this issue is not swept away by a few indigenous leaders who would have the government focusing on other things. Health is life. I know all Australians genuinely want to see indigenous health improve, which is a true form of practical reconciliation. It is the sort of thing that has been asked for in regional and remote communities, even if it is not being discussed in polite after-dinner conversations in our cities. Many recommendations in this report provide a clear starting point. I look forward to continuing to work with the government to build upon the recommendations and make real progress in this most important issue. I would like to thank all the wonderful people who cooperated with us in giving evidence and welcoming us into their communities. In conclusion, I would like to thank my fellow committee members for their cooperation and their sincerity in looking to a positive outcome with this report.

talk.start.para: —How do you hope to address the whole issue of indigenous health as raised in the report Health is life in a five-minute speech? I look forward to another opportunity in the Main Committee when I will have much longer to speak on this vitally important issue. The Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs has worked tirelessly over the past 2½ years to investigate all aspects of this important issue. We have visited dozens and dozens of communities in all states and territories. We have seen the excellent, the good, the bad and the ugly in urban, rural and remote indigenous communities when it comes to health service delivery.

speech.para: Several members of the committee have been with me since the inquiry's inception in the last parliament—Annette Ellis, Kay Elson, De-Anne Kelly, Harry Jenkins and Brendan Nelson. I would like to thank them for their commitment and dedication. As honourable members would know, this inquiry is one in a long line of inquiries into indigenous health. Adoption and implementation of the 35 recommendations will hopefully see the House not having to revisit this issue so thoroughly ever again. All we will need to do, hopefully, is closely monitor and finetune. The foundations will finally be in place to ensure that a health system for indigenous Australians is working just as well as it is for non-indigenous Australians.

During our inquiry, we spoke to all the key players involved in the supply of health services to indigenous Australians. What was very evident from the outset was the haphazard and scattergun approach to this whole issue. Like so much in this country, we saw the best and worst of the territorial and departmental approach to service delivery. Governments and their various departments have become very adept at cost shifting and blame apportioning when it comes to the whole issue of supplying health services to indigenous Australians. Because this issue is out of sight and out of mind of the vast number of Australians, all three tiers of government of all political persuasions have literally washed their hands of it. It is too difficult to fix and, besides, it is not going to rate all that highly when the pollsters check on issues that voters are getting upset about.

This committee has been determined from the outset of the inquiry to fix this problem once and for all. I have been known to frequently use the expression `It's a bloody shame' as we visited and took evidence at the many communities across the length and breadth of Australia during this inquiry. I, like others, would like to place on the public record my heartfelt tribute to the fantastic and amazing work done by Aboriginal health workers, nurses and doctors who toil tirelessly to provide services to our indigenous Australians. Especially, I would like to highlight those toiling so professionally in the remote regions. Please take a look at appendix C and see the places mentioned to get some idea of just how difficult it really is for these wonderful people to provide medical services for our indigenous brothers and sisters. As privileged Australians, we owe it not only to the disadvantaged and disenfranchised indigenous members of our society but to these dedicated health workers to see that our 35 recommendations are accepted and implemented as soon as possible.

I am not that naive to believe that our recommendations will solve all the problems once and forever. Canada, New Zealand and the United States have restructured and finetuned their health delivery to their indigenous peoples. They have radically lessened the mortality gap between indigenous and non-indigenous peoples in their countries. Our 35 recommendations have been written in a spirit of bipartisanship with a belief that we owe it to each and every indigenous community to deliver what we expect for each one of us—the most appropriate and the best health system, one that is culturally appropriate, adequately resourced and mindful of the need for diversity to reflect the urban, rural and remote aspect of health service delivery for our indigenous peoples.

Finally, I would like to place on record my appreciation for the work done by my fellow committee members and our wonderful secretariat—Angela, Belinda, Bjarne and Trevor. I would like to pay a special tribute to Jim Kennedy for his amazing professionalism, dedication, support and friendship over the past 2½ years as we worked on this report. I would also like to thank John Forrest, the member for Mallee, and Barry Wakelin, the member for Grey, the two committee chairs for this report. I urge all Australians to read this report and place pressure on all of us to see that we finally get it right this time. I highly recommend the report to the House.

talk.start.para: —If none of my colleagues opposite are going to jump up to speak, I would like to take the three or four minutes that are left. The Health is life report of the Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs is a very important report, one that I urge members of the House to take seriously, to read and to hopefully agree with most of its sentiment and most of its recommendations. But, even if members cannot agree with all of the recommendations, I hope they believe that this is a policy area we all must pay attention to.

speech.para: I represent an area where there are 504 indigenous people according to the 1996 census—that is, 0.4 per cent of the population. Indigenous affairs are not very high on the local agenda. My interest in indigenous people first came from having many of them as sporting heroes of mine and my family, but this inquiry has taught me that the issue of indigenous health is something that all Australians should take an interest in. Much of what is set out in the report is a roadmap for progressing many of the things that are under way at the moment. When we asked many people, they said, `There's no need to reinvent the wheel; there's a need to strengthen the existing rather than reinvent.' I hope that is the sentiment that the report portrays.

As the honourable member for Franklin alluded to, one of the working titles for this report was `A national disgrace', but that would have been too negative a title. It would not have acknowledged that, in many parts of Australia, much progress is being made. That is a tribute to all those who are involved. It is a tribute to all the governments and all the spheres of governments, but importantly it is a tribute to the communities, especially the non-indigenous communities. These are the communities that, given a chance, will be able to tackle this issue with the greatest success. That again is an overriding sentiment of this report.

I will take the opportunity in the Main Committee to express my thanks to the various people who have helped us—those who have been overwhelmingly helpful and open in the way that they have shared their experience. Much of the issues of indigenous health are to do with spiritual and cultural matters. They are difficult for us as non-indigenous people to understand, but this report and this inquiry gave us all the opportunity to listen to and share the experiences of those who are most affected.

talk.start.para: (Mr Nehl)—Order! The time allotted for statements on this report has expired. Does the member for Grey wish to move a motion in connection with the report to enable it to be debated on a future occasion?
—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker. I move:

motion.para: That the House take note of the report.

interjection.para: I seek leave to continue my remarks.

talk.start.para: —In accordance with standing order 102B, the debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting and the member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

debateinfo.title: TRADE PRACTICES AMENDMENT (UNCONSCIONABLE CONDUCT—SAVING OF STATE AND TERRITORY LAWS) BILL 2000

talk.start.para: —The private member's bill I am introducing today seeks to insert a savings provision into section 51AC of the Trade Practices Act. The effect of the amendment would be to allow state and territory governments to draw down the provisions of 51AC, without fear of having their legislation challenged under section 109 of the Constitution. Section 109 of the Constitution declares that, where a Commonwealth and state law are inconsistent, the Commonwealth law will prevail, and to the extent of inconsistency the state law will be rendered invalid.

speech.para: This is of real concern to the New South Wales government which, in 1998, passed amendments to its Retail Leases Act in an attempt to give small business tenants in New South Wales additional protection against unconscionable conduct. While the New South Wales parliament has passed those amendments—indeed, it passed them late in 1998—they are yet to be declared because, understandably, the Carr Labor government is concerned that a cashed-up landlord could seek to challenge those retail leases amendments under section 109 of the Constitution.

Since late 1998, the time of that legislation being passed, the New South Wales Minister for Small Business, Sandra Nori, has been writing to the Howard government, asking it to enact the necessary amendments to the Trade Practices Act to get around the concern that the New South Wales legislation could be challenged. In other words, for two years now, small business tenants in New South Wales have been denied the opportunity to seek redress through the very efficient remedies under the New South Wales act because of the Howard government's inability or unwillingness to make those necessary amendments.

The provisions contained within my private member's bill today replicate those that I moved by way of a trade practices amendment on 6 April this year. To my astonishment, the Howard government on that day chose to vote down those amendments. I say `to my astonishment' because I had in my possession at the time a letter from the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, Joe Hockey, to the New South Wales Minister for Small Business, Sandra Nori. In that letter, dated 25 October 1999—that is, a full year after Sandra Nori first made her request that that amendment be made—Minister Hockey stated:

quote.para: Concerning the draw down of section 51AC of the Trade Practices Act into states' retail leases legislation, I appreciate this particular amendment is important for the states and I realise that there are cogent reasons to bring forward this proposal as speedily as possible. Accordingly, I will be bringing the need for amendments to the Trade Practices Act to the attention of my ministerial colleagues in the near future and seeking approval for appropriate legislative amendments. I will ensure your office is advised once this has taken place. I look forward to achieving an outcome which will be welcome by everyone with an interest in this issue.

speech.para: Again I point out that that is from a letter written on 25 October 1999. So you can understand full well, I am sure, Mr Deputy Speaker, why I was surprised when the Howard government, on 6 April this year, chose to vote down an amendment I put into this parliament which would have given exactly that effect. No wonder I chose to put forward an amendment from the opposition side of the parliament because, at that point, it had been two years since the New South Wales government had passed its legislation and just as long since Sandra Nori first wrote to the Howard government seeking that amendment. I must say that that letter from Sandra Nori went through the hands of about three government ministers before landing in the lap of the unfortunate Joe Hockey and before Sandra Nori finally got that response.

The flow-on from all of that is that, some time soon after my amendment was voted down in this place, Minister Hockey announced by way of media release that the government would move to put in place the necessary amendments to give effect to that New South Wales leases amendment. That media release was issued on 10 May. So, in many regards, it could be said that the bill I am introducing today is redundant already; that is, the Howard government—after a lot of cajoling from both the opposition and the minister in New South Wales—has finally agreed to make the necessary amendments to allow the states to draw down 51AC of the Trade Practices Act.

But I see my decision to proceed with this bill today as insurance. There have now been two years of posturing from the government and it has now been at least two months since Minister Hockey made his announcement. On checking today with the office of Sandra Nori, the New South Wales Minister for Small Business, I have learned that the New South Wales government still has not been informed formally of the government's intention to move on this issue. Joe Hockey's announcement was made on 10 May, yet the New South Wales government still has not been informed formally of the government's intention to move on this issue. So I am determined to proceed with the introduction of this bill.

If in the next little while we still have not seen any formal response from the Howard government, I will continue to pursue this bill through to the second reading and, hopefully, another vote in the House of Representatives. This time around I hope that members of this place who have a genuine concern for small business and small business issues might see fit to extend that protection to small business tenants in New South Wales by giving their support to my bill.

The government has a bit of history, or a bit of form, in this area. Those who followed the Reid inquiry will know only too well how important retail lease legislation is to small business tenants. Throughout that inquiry, we heard some horrific case studies about how unconscionable landlords can be in their dealings with small business tenants. Unfortunately, but maybe not surprisingly given the very close relationship this government has with large business in this country, those who are typically the landlord in the battle, the government did not choose to adopt recommendation 2.1 of the Reid inquiry. That was a unanimous recommendation of parliamentarians from both sides of the political fence, and it sought in this country for the first time a uniform retail leases code.

Not surprisingly, recommendation 7 of last year's Joint Select Committee on the Retailing Sector, which was a unanimous view again of members of the House of Representatives and the Senate from all sides of politics on that committee, asked this government to act in the area of uniform retail tenancy legislation. Alas, when the government finally responded to the recommendations of that committee, it again dropped the ball on the retail leases issue. Why? It is because, as has been demonstrated time and time again, the government knows on what side its bread is buttered—that is, with the big end of town, those who are usually on the opposite side of the fence when it comes to these retail lease issues.

The question which has to be asked here is: where is the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business in all this? Again, Minister Reith has gone missing. He has gone missing on the GST. He has gone missing on Ralph. He has gone missing on a whole range of tax issues. He went missing on the revelation that private information being given to the ATO with respect to ABN applications is now being shared with larger companies seeking to build big databases and, therefore, seeking to exploit that information that was not only given in good faith but given as a legislative requirement, given under a cloud of punitive action against those who do not make that application.

Again, Minister Reith is missing in action. He was missing in action during budget week when the Howard government extraordinarily chose to cut all research for small business from the Commonwealth budget. Why is that so? Obviously the answer is fairly clear: Minister Reith and the Howard government do not want GST sentiment creeping into small business surveys or small business research. That is why the Howard government took the extraordinary step to cut the final year of funding to the small business longitudinal study, a five-year study initiated by the Keating government on which many researchers and many academics around this country were basing their own small business research. Without any warning, the final year is gone. That study is almost useless without that final year conclusion, yet the Howard government and Minister Reith, who are unwilling to do anything about it, chose to put political expediency before the small business sector and to simply cut that final year of research.

The Yellow Pages survey released last week makes one thing very clear: a very important constituency in this country that the Howard government used to claim as its own is turning against it in droves. Why should we be surprised? Not only has this government imposed a burdensome GST upon it; it has failed completely to introduce that GST in an efficient and uncomplicated way. Its greatest crime possibly is not the introduction of the GST but the haphazard and botched way it has sought to implement it. As a result, the small business constituency is turning against it, and we should not be surprised.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I hope you will indulge me for just a moment while I recognise in the gallery today my wife, Dianne, and three children—Caitlin, Jack and Grace—who do not make it down this way too often because of school commitments. With them is my good friend Graham Deloraine and his sons Matt, Eli and Jessie, and a good friend of them all young Jacob Woodbury. I thank the House for that indulgence.

If there is an engine room of growth in this country, it is the small business sector. It is well known that 60 per cent of the employment growth over the last 10 years has come from the small business sector. At this point in our history, a government of any political persuasion should be seeking to facilitate the growth of those small firms, and you do that in a number of ways. In the first instance, you do that by creating a climate of economic growth and a climate within which the price of money is low or, to say the same, interest rates are low. That is the first thing you do. But there are a number of other things you do. You seek to facilitate access to both debt and equity finance. When was the last time we heard Minister Reith talking about finance issues for small firms? Never. You never hear them mentioned.

The other thing you can do is ensure that small business has access to decent research. We will never achieve good public policy for small firms until we properly understand what makes them tick, until we properly understand what motivates small firms to grow or to not grow. That is very important, and on that basis I will not say that we have not seen Peter Reith at all on this issue but I will repeat what I said earlier and say that we have seen a bit of Minister Reith on this issue—a $2 million funding cut in small business research, in an attempt to put political expediency ahead of the interests of small business. This is a government which has two policies for small business—the introduction of the GST and the introduction of the so-called option 2 under the Ralph business tax reforms. Small business does not realise yet that the big hit is yet to come. Already struggling with the implementation of the GST, the small business sector has not yet realised what is coming out—that is, the adoption of option 2.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 1.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101. The debate may be resumed at a later hour and the member for Hunter will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

—On Thursday of last week Launceston, and indeed Tasmania, lost one of its great fighters. Sir Raymond Ferrall, who was born in Invermay in 1906, passed away peacefully in Launceston at the age of 94. In his lifetime he was part of many changes. He was born in Invermay, which in Launceston makes you a swampy, and died a knight of the realm and a freeman of Launceston city.

speech.para: In his extraordinary life he was a journalist, built a small grocery store into a major processing company, founded Qintex, was a warden of the Port of Launceston, was chair of the Tasmanian College of Advanced Education and fought tirelessly for the establishment of a northern campus of the Launceston University. And this does not even cover a quarter of his life and business experience. In his life, Sir Ray achieved the respect of businesses, community groups, national leaders and ordinary workers. He will be remembered at a memorial service in Launceston today. The community is the poorer for his passing but the richer for his life.

talk.start.para: —I want to take this opportunity to acknowledge the excellent work of Mountains Community Transport. In the 14 years it has been operating this organisation has provided a highly valued service for many disadvantaged people in the Blue Mountains—the frail aged, people with disabilities and their carers, and people who experience particular difficulties with transport. Residents of the Blue Mountains frequently see their vehicles ferrying clients to medical appointments, on shopping trips and on social outings. Last year their vehicles, along with those of volunteers, notched up close to 350,000 kilometres while attending to the needs of their client base which is approaching 1,700 people. The highly valued service owes much to the ability and commitment of the team, so capably led by Helen Walker and supplemented by a number of dedicated volunteers—amongst these Anne Ford and Ray Millard deserve special mention for their contribution.

speech.para: Two weeks ago Mountains Community Transport held its inaugural fundraising dinner and launched its Friends of Mountains Community Transport supporters program. I wish them well in this endeavour as they seek to enhance their capacity to serve the disadvantaged in the Blue Mountains. There are many in our community who would like to express their gratitude for the improvement to their lives provided by the committed team at Mountains Community Transport. I thank them for their work.

talk.start.para: —I would like to congratulate the Blacktown City Council on its 21st birthday that occurs tomorrow. On 6 June 1979 the first meeting of the Blacktown City Council was held in Bowman Hall and was chaired by the then mayor, John Aquilina, now member for Riverstone and New South Wales Minister for Education. In the 21 years since that important day, I am delighted to say that the City of Blacktown has made great progress under the careful guidance of many prominent mayors, including today's mayor, Alan Pendleton. There have also been many fine councillors and they all have played their part in the progress of Blacktown since 6 June 1979.

speech.para: The past 21 years of progress showed up last weekend in the participation rate at the Blacktown festival, and I am sure that the next 21 years will be equally as exciting and as adventurous as the first 21. The first meeting of the temporary council of Blacktown shire was held in the Rooty Hill School of Arts on Wednesday, 13 June 1906. Following this, elections were held and the first meeting of the Blacktown shire council took place on 8 December 1906. The first president was T. Willmot, and the expenditure of the council for its first year was £7,500 and the area's population at the time was 3,000.

subdebateinfo.title: Ballarat Electorate: World Environment Day Awards
Ballarat Electorate: Australian Catholic University

talk.start.para: —Over the weekend Australia picked up three of 14 World Environment Day awards, which was fantastic news. One of those groups was the Ballarat based Australian Trust for Conservation Volunteers. This group was started in Ballarat. It is now a national voluntary, nonprofit organisation, which completes more than 4,000 week-long conservation projects in urban regional and remote areas of Australia. It has planted nearly eight million trees since it has been going and it also manages the federally funded Green Corps program. I am sure that all honourable members would welcome a regional based organisation, national organisation, picking up a World Environment Day award like this. I congratulate the two other recipients. I say to the ATCV that I am very proud of you and I am sure that all members on all sides of the House representing rural and regional areas would appreciate the significance of a national based organisation being in a regional centre picking up one of these World Environment Day awards. It was fantastic news.

speech.para: While I am on my feet, I also congratulate the Aquinas campus of the Australian Catholic University where I had the great honour to be the occasional speaker on Saturday. Despite the fact that I locked my coat, my mortar board, my gown and indeed some speech notes in my office five minutes before the ceremony, I think all went reasonably well. But I do congratulate this fine campus of a fine university. Ballarat is blessed to have both the Aquinas campus of the ACU and the Ballarat University, both fine institutions.

subdebateinfo.title: Charlton Electorate: Cowan Mine Survival Unit

talk.start.para: —Tomorrow on-site testing will begin at the new Cowan Mine Survival Unit at Myuna Colliery in my electorate. The Cowan Mine Survival Unit is aimed at improving safety and emergency procedures for underground miners. I can proudly boast that Cowan Manufacturing is located in my electorate of Charlton at Warners Bay. The company has existed since 1973 and is recognised worldwide for its work in the development and manufacture of decompression chambers. Bob Cowan's grandfather and father were miners and it is fitting that Bob has developed this unit to help make underground mining safer. The Cowan MSU is a mobile unit which has its own air, water and communications and can accommodate up to 12 men for up to 24 hours. It houses safety equipment and is placed underground for use by miners in case of an emergency. I extend my congratulations and my thanks to Bob Cowan and the team at Cowan Manufacturing, to the CFMEU for their participation and to Powercoal as a partner in the Mine Survival Unit which will assist in saving the lives of miners involved in underground emergencies.
—I would like to make mention of the festivities that were held for Italian National Day on the weekend.

speech.para: Honourable members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —There is strong support for the Italian community in Australia in the chamber at this moment. I start firstly with the cocktail party to farewell the Consul of Italy, Dr Tony D'Alessandro, and his wife, Paola, who will be returning to Italy after a four-year stint in Brisbane. I am sure they will remember Brisbane very fondly because not only did they serve the community tirelessly but it was also the place where their two children were born. I am sure they will remember Brisbane for many years to come—in fact, whenever they look and see `Brisbane' on their passports.

speech.para: I also want to acknowledge the wonderful work that is done by the CO.AS.IT Association, the welfare arm of the Italian community, and the successful ball that I attended on Saturday night. They do tremendous work with pensioners and, along with the Catholic Education Office, to promote Italian language and culture in schools. It was wonderful to see so many people turn up for the ball and help in this fantastic fundraising venture. I know their social welfare group will continue to work tirelessly for the community.

Yesterday I also had the privilege of attending the opening of the Italian Festival at the Italian Australia Centre in Newmarket. The day was glorious. I must say it was absolutely fantastic to see all the wonderful stalls set up with the different areas, and I thoroughly enjoyed it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —While the government continues to put the decision of the second Sydney airport in the too-hard basket, it leaves open the possibility that it may seek to satisfy the demands of some of its members by developing Bankstown Airport as a centre for intrastate air travel. The further development of Bankstown Airport is unthinkable given the limitations of the site and the impact of heavier air traffic on areas close to the airport. Bankstown is the busiest airport in Australia with over 450,000 movements each year compared to less than 300,000 at Mascot. The flight path goes directly over the centre of Liverpool, impacting on a number of schools and the major teaching hospital located there. Other flight paths intrude on residential areas of Lansvale, Cabramatta and Canley Vale. Forty-six per cent of traffic at Bankstown already involves intrastate air charter operations. Any expansion by adding the bulk of scheduled intrastate flights would place a greater burden on residents in the Fowler electorate. Heavier and noisier aircraft would no doubt follow such development. This government should immediately rule out any expansion of operations at Bankstown Airport.

—I rise today to congratulate the people of Armidale and the surrounding district of Dumaresq on their newly formed Armidale-Dumaresq Council. This has been a voluntary amalgamation over a period of some time. The first election was held last Saturday week. We all applaud the fact that local government is the grassroots level, and it was wonderful to see 28 candidates stand in this local government election to select 10 people. Those 10 people include Peter Ducat, an earthmoving contractor; Brian Kelly, a stock transporter; Peter Monley, the past interim mayor; Pat Dixon, the past deputy mayor; Roger Patricks, a retailer and past councillor on the Armidale City Council; Brian Chetwyn, another small business person, first time elected, which I think is great; Ken Waters, a local grazier; Herman Beyersdorf from the university; Sue King, a previous councillor on the Armidale City Council; and Laurie Knight, a valuer.

speech.para: It certainly goes to show that people are interested in local government, that they are keen to have a voice. As I have often said in this place, there is no point standing on the sidelines or yelling abuse or suggestions. The best thing to do is get in there, have your say and be part of the decision making process rather than leave it to somebody else. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I want to begin by thanking all the members of parliament, parliamentary staff and others who have sent greetings to me and my wife, Kathryn, on the birth of our little girl, Margaret Persephone Theophanous. She was born on 7 May at 11.18 p.m., and we are obviously very grateful and very thrilled about her arrival. I will be writing to people individually to send them our greetings.

speech.para: I want to refer to two matters that have occurred in my absence relating to issues that have concerned me in my parliamentary work. Firstly, I want to express concern about the developments that have occurred in relation to the three-year visa that this parliament adopted late last year.
